content.text: The OEE Charge System is a smart power control system built around the ESP8266 microcontroller. It allows users to control electrical devices via a custom web-server interface, with manual and scheduled control options.
The system is equipped with 4 relay modules to manage high-voltage devices or appliances, an LCD display for system statuses and messages, scheduled countdowns, and an exhaust fan for cooling.
System Components & Build Process

This is the documentary of how I built OEE Charge System. It all started from scratch, Arduino & quite fun to learn and it took me 1/2 month to complete this project. The internal layout shows the careful organization of components for optimal heat dissipation and wire management.

Building this system involved thorough testing to ensure it could handle high-voltage loads reliably. I experimented with different relay modules to ensure power delivery and various fan configurations to prevent overheating. Finding the right balance between performance and durability was key to creating a stable system.

This documentation serves as a helpful guide for anyone interested in building similar projects. Whether you're a beginner looking to learn the basics of microcontrollers or a seasoned DIY enthusiast, this system highlights various modules and gives opportunities to improve design thinking for high performance. Making it an ideal resource for anyone wanting to explore or test power management solutions.

articles.title: Building a Social Media Prototype from Scratch
articles.author: Jerome Edica

content.text: Building a social media platform from scratch is an ambitious project that brought together everything I've learned about web development. This prototype showcases what happens when you combine creativity with determination to create something meaningful from nothing.

The platform features all the essentials you'd expect from a social network: user profiles where people can express themselves, a dynamic news feed that updates in real-time, the ability to share posts and photos, and interactive features like comments and likes. Users can connect with others, follow their updates, and build their own community within the platform.

The biggest challenge wasn't the code itself, but designing an experience that felt intuitive and engaging. How do you organize information so it's easy to find? How do you make interactions feel instant and responsive? These questions drove countless iterations and improvements throughout the development process.

This project taught me that building something from scratch requires patience, problem-solving, and a willingness to learn as you go. Every feature added, every bug fixed, and every design decision made contributed to my growth as a developer. It's proof that with enough passion and persistence, you can create something impressive on your own.

The Edica Project Drone (EPD) Penta Copter represents my first venture into drone design and 3D modeling. Created in early 2024, this realistic 3D model showcases a five-rotor aerial vehicle designed with attention to aerodynamics and visual appeal.

Unlike traditional quadcopters, the penta copter configuration offers enhanced stability and redundancy. With five rotors instead of four, the drone can maintain flight even if one motor fails, making it a safer and more reliable design for aerial applications.

The entire model was crafted in Blender, focusing on realistic proportions, materials, and details. From the carbon fiber frame texture to the precise placement of electronic components, every element was carefully considered to create a believable and functional-looking design.

This project taught me valuable lessons about 3D modeling workflows, lighting techniques for rendering, and the fundamentals of drone architecture. It's the foundation for future projects involving actual drone construction and flight controller programming.

articles.title: Leading the National Science Expo Team
articles.author: Jerome Edica

content.text: I still remember the nerves I felt during my very first Research Congress. Standing there, unsure of what the outcome would be, I told myself: 'Win or lose, this experience is good, and I've learned so much.' That mindset carried me through, and it became the foundation of everything that followed.

I owe deep gratitude to my teachers, coaches, group members, and the National Expo Team. Their guidance and support made it possible for us to compete in Lucena, Quezon. And to those who believed in us, especially Tagkawayan National High School, this fight was for you.
Leading the National Science Expo Team

I was chosen to lead our school's National Science Expo team, representing Tagkawayan National High School. That journey became one of the proudest moments of my life. Our research caught attention, set a benchmark at school, and opened doors to interviews and opportunities including recognition from De La Salle University.
But I made a choice: to protect what I had built. Instead of chasing external offers, I focused on strengthening my own project, an innovation that was ahead of its time.
Building an Offline AI Chatbot for Students
Back then, Meta AI was not yet popular or integrated into Messenger. So I turned to open-source tools and built something unique: a custom offline chatbot powered by AI.

content.text: In short, I wanted to break the limits of internet dependency so students could learn anytime, anywhere. At some point, I felt like I was bending the rules of the internet itself, but the mission was clear: to make learning accessible for everyone.
Science and Technology: A Pathway to Change

Science and technology are truly amazing. They do not just give us tools, they give us opportunities to transform lives. My journey, from nervous beginnings at the Research Congress to building an offline AI educational kit, proves that innovation can start anywhere, even in a small school in Quezon.
And this is only the beginning.

After the event in the National Science Technology Fair, I was chosen again to join the solo research event in school. That time I felt both excited and nervous, because for me I am not good at writing papers. But for them, they believed I could be more. They saw my strength, that I can compose bright ideas to solve real-world problems.
The Three-Hour Challenge

The challenge was tough. They gave us a problem about flood solutions in Quezon Province, and all participants had to create a complete research paper from Chapter 1 to Chapter 5 in just three hours, right on our seats.

Most of us did not finish it, and afterward everyone was called one by one to defend their research. I felt great because someone from Class A applauded me and said, "Ang galing mo kanina." That moment was probably the best part of the experience.
Coming Soon: My Flood Control Research
As for my flood control research, I will share more details in my next blog.
Hmm, it's been a month, na miss ko mag code.
Record: Rank 9 WT Philippines

For being one of the most active developers back then, I used to code without much sleep. The dedication and countless hours spent building and creating pushed me to achieve something I'm proud ofâ€”reaching Rank 9 in WT Philippines.

Those days were intense. Every line of code felt like progress, every project was a step forward. The community, the challenges, the late-night debugging sessionsâ€”they all became part of who I am as a developer.
The Goal Ahead
Hmm, I'm thinking of reaching rank 1 soon.
The journey continues. After a month away from coding, the passion is still there, maybe even stronger. Time to get back to what I love and aim for the top.
